DOCNAME: CASE OF BATIĆ AND OTHERS v. SERBIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Enforcement proceedings;Article 6-1 - Access to court);Violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Protection of property (Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Peaceful enjoyment of possessions)
JUDGES: Branko Lubarda;Georgios A. Serghides;Pere Pastor Vilanova
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered a socially - owned company DP PK Delišes ( hereinafter “ the debtor company ” ) , based in PERSON , to pay the first applicant specified amounts on account of debt , plus the costs of the civil proceedings . This judgment became final on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the first applicant ’s request to that effect , ORG ordered the enforcement of the said judgment and further ordered the debtor company to pay the first applicant the enforcement costs .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor company ( St. CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . As a result , the ongoing enforcement proceedings against the debtor company were stayed by ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . The first applicant duly submitted his respective claim .
CARDINAL . The insolvency proceedings against the debtor company are still ongoing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant lodged a constitutional appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found a violation of the first applicant ’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time . It further awarded him MONEY ( ORG ) as just satisfaction for non - pecuniary damage . ORG dismissed the first applicant ’s complaint concerning his right to the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions as well as his request for pecuniary damages , since the insolvency proceedings were still pending . That decision was delivered to the first applicant on DATE .
CARDINAL . The second applicant was born in DATE and lives in LOC .
CARDINAL . He was employed by ORG EI-CARDINAL ORG , a socially - owned company based in LOC ( hereinafter “ the debtor company ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant concluded the settlement with the debtor company before ORG , by which the debtor company was obliged to pay the second applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions , plus the costs of the civil proceedings . This settlement became final on an unspecified date .

CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the second applicant ’s request to that effect , ORG ordered the enforcement of the said settlement and further ordered the debtor company to pay the second applicant the enforcement costs .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the debtor company to pay the second applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions , plus the costs of the civil proceedings . This judgment became final by DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the second applicant ’s request to that effect , ORG ordered the enforcement of the said judgment and further ordered the debtor company to pay the second applicant the enforcement costs .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE respectively , ORG ordered the debtor company to pay the second applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears and social insurance contributions . These decisions became final on unspecified dates .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE respectively , upon the second applicant ’s request to that effect , ORG ordered the enforcement of the said decisions and further ordered the debtor company to pay the second applicant the enforcement costs .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor company ( St. CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . As a result , the ongoing enforcement proceedings against the debtor company were stayed .
CARDINAL . The second applicant duly submitted his respective claims .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant ’s claims were formally recognised .
CARDINAL . The insolvency proceedings against the debtor company are still ongoing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant lodged a constitutional appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed his appeal as lodged out of time . It found that the second applicant failed to lodge his appeal within DATE as of the date when the decisions on the staying of the enforcement proceedings as a result of opening of the insolvency proceedings had been delivered to him . That decision was delivered to the second applicant after DATE .
CARDINAL . The third applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .
CARDINAL . He was employed by ORG , a socially - owned company based in PERSON ( hereinafter “ the debtor company ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the third applicant concluded the settlement with the debtor company before ORG , by which the debtor company was obliged to pay the third applicant specified amounts on account of salary arrears , plus the costs of the civil proceedings . This settlement became final on an unspecified date .

CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the third applicant ’s request to that effect , ORG ordered the enforcement of the said settlement and further ordered the debtor company to pay the third applicant the enforcement costs .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG opened insolvency proceedings in respect of the debtor company ( St. CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . The third applicant duly submitted his respective claim .
CARDINAL . On DATE the third applicant ’s claim was formally recognised .
CARDINAL . On DATE the third applicant was paid PERCENT of his recognized claim .
CARDINAL . The insolvency proceedings against the debtor company are still ongoing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the third applicant lodged a constitutional appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed his appeal as lodged out of time . It found that the third applicant failed to lodge his appeal within DATE as of the date when the decision on opening of the insolvency proceedings had been rendered or as of the date when he had submitted his claim in the insolvency proceedings . That decision was delivered to the third applicant on DATE .
